Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Semiconductor Diode for High Temperature Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This I-Corps Team project seeks to investigate the commercialization potential of Schottky diodes capable of operating at temperatures in excess of 600C. Schottky barrier diodes are used in wireless technologies for commercial and military needs, high efficiency switches for power distribution, sensors, photovoltaic inverters, and in the automobile industry. Schottky barrier diodes made from SiC currently available commercially are limited to operating temperatures below 300C. It is widely accepted that the development of electronic systems capable of high temperature operations above 300C, without the need for cooling, is a critical technology for current and future applications. The ability to operate electronic components in harsh conditions advances technology across a broad spectrum of applications. The proposed new technology is poised to expand the innovation boundaries set by current temperature limitations. If successful, this could lead to commercialization of other electronic components. Target applications include power systems for oil-drilling, automotive, aerospace and space exploration.

The goal of this project is to determine the commercialization potential of Schottky diodes capable of operating at temperatures in excess of 600C. The innovation in our technology comes from the materials used as the metal contacts (refractory metal borides and nickel gallide) as well as the unique processing techniques employed. This process removes deleterious but inherent oxides that form at the interface. This technology can also be extended to fabricate transistors with similarly improved high temperature reliability. The new technology could lead to the reduction or complete elimination of expensive cooling systems in high temperature electronics operation. Funds from this I-Corps Team project will enable assessment of interest among the electronics community addressing target markets. This project offers opportunity to further the team's understanding of the market opportunity for the technology. The workshops and interviews will help the team gain perspectives on the target customers and thereby lead them to either a licensing pathway, a spin-out SBIR/STTR pathway for further development, or a commercial partnership to accomplish both. Since the scope of the opportunity is rather wide, the team will use information gathered from this project to prioritize the deployment of limited resources towards sectors that offer the highest probability of commercial success.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was conduct several customer discovery interviews in order to determine whether the semiconductor diodes developed through prior NSF funds by the PI has viable commercial potential. Our team comprised the Principal Investigator (Dr. Tom Oder, Professor of Physics at Youngstown State University), the student Entrepreneurial Lead (Krishna Kundeti, graduate student at Youngstown State University) and the Team Mentor (Mr. Dave Nestic, Chief Executive, TechBelt Energy Innovation Center, Warren, OH). Over 112 customer interviews were conducted with potential customers comprising engineers, sales representatives. These covered Oil/Gas drilling, Automotive, Aviation, Space Exploration and Industrial Manufacturing industries. The interviews were either in person, via Skype or telephone, covering the states of Ohio, Pennsylvania, Georgia, West Virginia, Indiana, Michigan, California, New Mexico and Alabama. A few interviews were made with customers in Canada and the United Kingdom.  

 

The following were the major outcomes of this project:

  1. Our existing technology focused and demonstrated only on Schottky barrier diodes was not sufficient to enter the market. We discovered that there was a great need for electronics that enables function at high temperature, but a single component was not sufficient. The technology needs to be implemented on a sub-system that can perform a major task. In our case, we identified such a subsystem as the Voltage Reference capable of functioning at 400 oC and above for analogue integrated circuits. Such a sub-system would comprise Schottky diodes and metal semiconductor field effect transistors (MESFETs) which would be fabricated using our technology. At the conclusion of the training program, our decision was a “No-Go”. We have since returned to the laboratory and vigorously pursuing the implementation of our technology to fabricate MESFETs and Junction Barrier Schottky diodes (JBS). Two epitaxial wafers of silicon carbide wafers have been purchased and 8 glass photomasks have been designed and acquired. The JBS and MESFETs are in various stages of fabrication and will be followed by long term high temperature testing.
  2. Another major outcome from this project is a complete change of research focus for the PI and the student Entrepreneurial Lead. Previously, we approached research with the goal of generating peer reviewed publications and perhaps providing better understanding on a process or a technique for developing a product. After this training, we now look at research with the goal of developing a product of potential market value. We keep in mind the question “Why would someone want to spend money to buy this product?”.
  3. Another outcome from this project was what we learnt from the pace and pressure with which the interviews had to be conducted. It quickly became clear to us that we needed to get out of our comfort zone and fully devote more time and energy if we are going to succeed in any commercialization venture.
  4. Collaboration with regional/national industries through connection provided by the Mentor. We now have many contacts with regional and national industries. This is a significant outcome because now we can reach out to most of these contacts for collaborations. As an example, we have established research collaboration with the Center for High Performance Power Electronics in Columbus, OH. We are now more closely connected to the TechBelt Energy Innovation Center located in the city of Warren near YSU.
